History of Present Illness:
Mr. ___ is a ___ year old male with recent partial nephrectomy 
___ who presents now with fevers to 102.0 and pleuritic 
chest and rib pain. The left-sided rib and LUQ pain began three 
days ago, suddenly, and has progressively worsened with 
pleuritic component. He noted feeling severe chills and 
continued to feel very cold over teh last few days. It is 
associated with deep inspiration and cough but does not occur at 
rest. He was able to walk around the block yesterday without any 
issues.  
 He reports that the only medications he is taking are vitamin D 
and metoprolol. He was told to hold all other medications until 
his next PCP ___. HE denies any recent long travel or 
flights.  
 His family history is significant for venous thrombus in his 
father and brother, ___ post-operative. He denies dyspnea on 
exertion. He denies lower extremity asymmetric swelling or upper 
extremity asymmetric swelling. He is only taking Tylenol for the 
pain. He denies any urinary symptoms or diarrhea. He continues 
to void well without pain and has excellent appetite.  
 Regarding his left nephrectomy, he was originally seen in ___ and was found to have incidental left lower pole renal 
complex cyst. He was followed carefully with urology and the 
cyst was noted to have slight growth to a max of 6cm. There were 
also other cysts in the kidney that appeared benign. Patient 
decided to proceed with left partial nephrectomy. Following the 
procedure, he was monitored by urology for three days without 
any evidence of complications. His pain was well controlled on a 
PCA and he was transitioned to oral oxycodone on discharge.  
 Note that during the nephrectomy, Urology removed two masses 
and one cyst from his left kidney.  
 The cyst was found to be benign. However, the subsequent two  
 masses were found to be malignant. The first tumor removed was  

 5.5 cm, clear cell, papillary carcinoma, 5.5-cm, low-grade, 
stage  
 1 and completely resected. The second tumor was a 9 mm  
 tubulo-cystic carcinoma, low-grade, stage I, also completely  
 resected with negative margins. Urology felt this was a 
favorable report and recommended no need for adjuvant therapy.  
 In the ED, initial vitals were:  
 T 102.7 HR 105 BP ___ RR 18 O2 Sat 98% RA

 -No CVAT

 -Some mild left lower quadrant tenderness

 Coags: ___ 13.2 PTT 25.6 INR 1.2  
 EKG showing normal sinus rhythm, normal axis, normal intervals, 
without ST changes.  
 - Imaging was notable for:  
 1) CT Head without acute intracranial process  
 2) CXR with opacity at the left lung suggestive of atelectasis 
vs. pneumonia. No large effusion or pneumothorax. 
Cardiomediastinal silhouette appears normal.  
 3) CT torso with contrast: bilateral lower lobe segmental and 
subsegmental pulmonary emboli with lower lobe consolidations 
likely representing a combination of atelectasis and infarction. 
No evidence of right heart strain. Postsurgical changes 
involving the left kidney reflecting partial nephrectomy without 
evidence of acute complication.  
 - Patient was given:  
 Tylenol ___ x 2  
 1L NS  
 5mg Oxycodone  
 Heparin drip  
 Urology was consulted in the ED due to patient being one month 
out from partial nephrectomy. They noted no contraindication to 
anticoagulation from urology perspective and recommended 
hematology follow-up given family history of recurrent PEs.  
 Upon arrival to the floor, patient reports that his pain is 
much better now that he received oxycodone. His pain decreased 
from ___. He continues to endorse good appetite without 
nausea or vomiting. He has a little anxiety related to hospital 
stay. He has not had any difficulty with urinating. He does not 
have any dysuria or diarrhea.

Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ is a ___ year old male with recent partial nephrectomy 
___ who presented with PE. He was discharged on apixaban 
BID, and instructed to follow-up with outpatient hematology. 

# Submassive Pulmonary Embolism
# Left lower extremity DVT
Patient presented with shortness of breath, corroborated by CT 
torso showing bilateral lower lobe segmental and subsegmental 
pulmonary emboli. Patient hemodynamically stable without 
evidence of respiratory distress. Trop negative, BNP wnl. Lower 
extremity US + for DVT. He was started on a heparin drip then 
transitioned to apixaban. He had anticardiolipin and anti-beta 2 
glycoprotein sent off. He will need hematology follow up here 
for further testing given family history. Pain managed with 
tylenol, oxycodone, lidocaine patch. Please ensure patient is 
uptodate with age-appropriate cancer screening. Patient should 
continue apixaban 10mg BID for a total of 7 days (___), and 
then decrease dose to 5mg BID for minimum of 3 months. 

# LV Hypokinesis/Akinesis
Seen on TTE for work up of R heart strain. TTE notable for 
"normal left ventricular wall thickness with a normal cavity 
size. Global left ventricular systolic function is normal. 
However, there is focal hypokinesis/akinesis of the inferior and 
posterior walls." Patient should be considered for aspirin and 
high dose statin, as well as outpatient stress testing.  We 
increased his dose of atorvastatin from 10 mg daily to 40 mg 
daily.

#Fever 
Febrile to 102 on admission. No clear localizing symptoms, no 
WBC elevation, UA negative, pending cultures. CTA chest and 
abdomen without signs of infection. Likely related to pulmonary 
infarction. He was afebrile x24 hrs by discharge.

# Left renal cyst S/p nephrectomy
# Clear cell papillocarcinoma
# Tubulo-cystic carcinoma
Patient underwent recent nephrectomy on ___ with removal of 
cyst as well as two malignant lesions. Negative margins were 
noted without any recommendation for adjuvant therapy. He was 
cleared for anticoagulation by urology from a surgical 
post-operative standpoint. He will need to follow up with 
urology for monitoring of his resected renal cell carcinoma. 

# BPH
# Lower urinary tract symptoms:
Patient's most recent PSA was 2.94/ normal on ___ at ___. 
Urology planned to repeat a PSA in 6 months. He has no family 
history of prostate cancer. Our CT abdomen/pelvis noted 
"Heterogeneous enlarged prostate for which clinical correlation 
is advised with physical exam and PSA." His PSA was 3.3. He 
should continue urology followup for his BPH and renal cell 
monitoring as above.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___,

It was a pleasure to care for you during this admission,

Why was I admitted to the hospital?
- You were found to have a pulmonary embolism (blood clot in the 
lung)

What happened while I was admitted?
- You had a CT scan of your chest which showed the blood clot in 
the lung
- You had an ultrasound of your leg which showed a clot 
- You had an ultrasound of your heart which was concerning for 
coronary artery disease
- We gave you blood thinning medication to treat your blood 
clots

What should I do when I leave the hospital?
- Please continue taking your medications, especially your 
apixaban 10mg two times per day. 
- Starting on ___, decrease the dose of your apixaban to 5mg 
two times per day
- Please follow up with your primary care doctor within 1 week, 
as well as your other appointments listed below

We wish you all the best,
